elements.content: We demonstrate a new de novo synthetic methodology to achieve high-temperature-stable compelled composite superhydrophobic porous coordination polymers (PCPs). These new PCPs were achieved based on coordination capabilities of first-row transition metal ions such as Co2+, Ni2+, and Zn2+. The obtained composite PCPs containing a [Zn2M2O]6+ (M = Co or Ni) bimetallic cluster core with open metal sites (OMSs) exhibited distinct isosteric heats of adsorption and surface areas due to the difference in their open metal Lewis acidic sites of solvent-free state. Additionally, these composite PCPs exhibit remarkable superhydrophobic properties with contact angles of 159.3° and 160.8° respectively for Zn–Co and Zn–Ni analogues. This superhydrophobic surface survives even at high temperature for longer time periods. As projected, these new composite PCPs exhibit better surface area and heats of adsorption compared to the PESD-1 (Zn) analogue due to a larger number of OMSs. Moreover, they display selective adsorption toward aromatic solvents such as benzene and toluene over aliphatic solvents such as cyclohexane due to corrugated and terminated aromatic hydrocarbon moieties toward the interactive surface. They also exhibit oil spill cleanup from the water surface in the powder form as well as pellet form up to 385 wt %. This study certainly offers a roadmap for designing and engineering new composite superhydrophobic porous materials for better water and thermal stability along with OMSs. This type of PCP exhibits a wide range of applications especially in catalysis, separation technology, and securing environmental problems such as oil spill cleanup in seawater.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), which are also known as porous coordination polymers (PCPs), have emerged as potential materials of the decade due to numerous applications in surface technology. The revolution of MOFs/PCPs has come due to their designable functionality according to the requirement, compared with conventional porous materials, such as activated carbon, zeolite, and related porous materials. The functionality in PCPs could be achieved mainly in two different parts of the PCP compounds. It could be at the ligand part or at the metal cluster core part. In the literature the potentiality of reduced symmetry linkers has been reported; having one type of coordinating group in different chemical environments offers the potential to expose new regions of phase space. This enables the discovery of novel materials with feasible innovative metal–oxygen–metal (M–O–M) clusters.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which are also known as porous coordination polymers (PCPs), have emerged as potential materials of the decade due to numerous applications in surface technology. The revolution of MOFs/PCPs has come due to their designable functionality according to the requirement, compared with conventional porous materials, such as activated carbon, zeolite, and related porous materials. The functionality in PCPs could be achieved mainly in two different parts of the PCP compounds. It could be at the ligand part or at the metal cluster core part. In the literature the potentiality of reduced symmetry linkers has been reported; having one type of coordinating group in different chemical environments offers the potential to expose new regions of phase space. This enables the discovery of novel materials with feasible innovative metal-oxygen-metal (M-O-M) clusters.

elements.content: It is well-known that the inorganic backbone (M–O–M linkage clusters) of the PCPs plays a vital role in their thermal and chemical stability. In many cases, the inorganic moiety could be just a metal, after removal of the guest-solvent molecules leads to collapse of the structure or shows very low thermal stability. Recently, we have reported an asymmetrical ligand, benzene-1,3,5-tris­(m-benzoic acid) (H3BTMB), based on the first superhydrophobic PCP with external surface design (PESD-1) and a dense IIO3 superhydrophobic framework, Pb­[(H-BTMB)­(DMF)], exhibiting selective adsorption of CO2. In fact, these two PCPs possess superhydrophobicity due to the highly corrugated aromatic hydrocarbon surface directed toward the guest species along with a unique type of open metal sites (OMSs).
elements.clean_text: It is well-known that the inorganic backbone (M-O-M linkage clusters) of the PCPs plays a vital role in their thermal and chemical stability. In many cases, the inorganic moiety could be just a metal, after removal of the guest-solvent molecules leads to collapse of the structure or shows very low thermal stability. Recently, we have reported an asymmetrical ligand, benzene-1,3,5-tris(m-benzoic acid) (H3BTMB), based on the first superhydrophobic PCP with external surface design (PESD-1) and a dense IIO3 superhydrophobic framework, Pb[(H-BTMB)(DMF)], exhibiting selective adsorption of CO2. In fact, these two PCPs possess superhydrophobicity due to the highly corrugated aromatic hydrocarbon surface directed toward the guest species along with a unique type of open metal sites (OMSs).

elements.content: MOFs/PCPs containing OMSs display promising applications especially in catalysis, gas separation, and storage. Particularly, OMSs play a substantial role in gas separation technology, where a particular gas can strongly coordinate with a particular type of OMS. In fact, many MOFs/PCPs reported in the literature lack OMSs after the evacuation of guest molecules. Nevertheless, in some MOFs/PCPs, metal clusters and/or metal ions coordinated to solvent molecules in as-synthesized form, and they could be ambiguous after the evacuation of the guest molecules. In reality, OMSs could not be generated in many PCPs even after activation by removal of solvent molecules, because they fill coordination spaces without bonding to metals. In some PCPs, metals coordinated by solvent molecules could be converted to unstable OMSs after removal of the molecules. In this context, construction of PCPs with stable OMSs is a valuable approach for various applications in the field of porous materials. In the present study, we focused on functionalization of PCPs at a metal cluster core part (composite PCPs) for more open metal sites by choosing high coordination ability (Co2+ and Ni2+) transition metal ions in place of the four-coordinate Zn2+ ion in PESD-1 PCP. These new composite PCPs are expected to display more OMSs along with high water stability (superhydrophobicity) and good thermal stability (due to the bimetallic cluster core).

elements.content: Herein, we report a de novo synthetic method for the synthesis of composite PCPs, PESD-2 and -3, [Zn2M2(μ3-OH)2(BTMB)2] (M = Co and Ni). The oxo-clusters in the pristine phases of PESD-2&3⊃Guest have converted to [Zn2M2O]6+ (M = Co and Ni) clusters with OMSs in their degassed phases by losing a water molecule. Additionally, these new composite PCPs exhibit outstanding superhydrophobic properties compared to other M4O clusters containing MOFs (hygroscopic) reported in the literature.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report a de novo synthetic method for the synthesis of composite PCPs, PESD-2 and -3, [Zn2M2(μ3-OH)2(BTMB)2] (M = Co and Ni). The oxo-clusters in the pristine phases of PESD-2&3⊃Guest have converted to [Zn2M2O]6+ (M = Co and Ni) clusters with OMSs in their degassed phases by losing a water molecule. Additionally, these new composite PCPs exhibit outstanding superhydrophobic properties compared to other M4O clusters containing MOFs (hygroscopic) reported in the literature.

elements.content: The first superhydrophobic PCP, PESD-1⊃Guest, was successfully achieved, in which the [Zn4(μ3-OH)2]6+ cluster core with OMSs is the provocative part of the PCP for applications such as gas separation and catalysis. In fact, that the [Zn4(μ3-OH)2]6+ cluster core changes to [Zn4O]6+ reversibly by losing a H2O molecule in the degassed phase and vice versa by exposing OMS on Zn2+ is very peculiar and contrasts the reported M4O cluster containing MOFs (no OMSs). These unique properties such as superhydrophobicity and OMSs together in a single PCP of PESD-1 are used for other analogues of this PCP. Consequently, we focused on the synthesis of PESD-1 analogues using other divalent transition metals in order to increase the number of OMSs for selective interactions with various gas molecules. We screened for all the first-row transition elements using similar solvothermal conditions to those employed for PESD-1⊃Guest along with other possible methods. However, we could not synthesize any analogue of PESD-1 with one single metal alone at all four metal centers of the Zn4(μ3-OH)2]6+ cluster. This could be due to the fact that first-row transition metals prefer six-coordination (except Zn). In this context, we thought of introducing various M2+ ions specifically at the two octahedral-coordinating Zn2+ ion sites of the [Zn4(μ3-OH)2]6+ oxo-cluster ((b)). The other two tetrahedral-coordinating Zn2+ ions are retained in the structure and chemical formula, which is useful to stabilize the structure. Recently, bimetallic PCPs with M4O clusters having four-coordination were synthesized by soaking single crystals consisting of one metal in a solution of another metal ion. We employed a different approach of a direct solvothermal synthetic approach based on our hypothesis that first-row divalent transition metal ions (except Zn2+) could occupy only an octahedral position. By this method, we could successfully introduce Co2+ and Ni2+ ions precisely at the octahedral Zn2+ ion site of the [Zn4(μ3-OH)2]6+ oxo-cluster (b) to synthesize the present composites, PESD-2&3⊃Guest PCPs.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses

The first superhydrophobic PCP, PESD-1⊃Guest, was successfully achieved, in which the [Zn4(μ3-OH)2]6+ cluster core with OMSs is the provocative part of the PCP for applications such as gas separation and catalysis. In fact, that the [Zn4(μ3-OH)2]6+ cluster core changes to [Zn4O]6+ reversibly by losing a H2O molecule in the degassed phase and vice versa by exposing OMS on Zn2+ is very peculiar and contrasts the reported M4O cluster containing MOFs (no OMSs). These unique properties such as superhydrophobicity and OMSs together in a single PCP of PESD-1 are used for other analogues of this PCP. Consequently, we focused on the synthesis of PESD-1 analogues using other divalent transition metals in order to increase the number of OMSs for selective interactions with various gas molecules. We screened for all the first-row transition elements using similar solvothermal conditions to those employed for PESD-1⊃Guest along with other possible methods. However, we could not synthesize any analogue of PESD-1 with one single metal alone at all four metal centers of the Zn4(μ3-OH)2]6+ cluster. This could be due to the fact that first-row transition metals prefer six-coordination (except Zn). In this context, we thought of introducing various M2+ ions specifically at the two octahedral-coordinating Zn2+ ion sites of the [Zn4(μ3-OH)2]6+ oxo-cluster ((b)). The other two tetrahedral-coordinating Zn2+ ions are retained in the structure and chemical formula, which is useful to stabilize the structure. Recently, bimetallic PCPs with M4O clusters having four-coordination were synthesized by soaking single crystals consisting of one metal in a solution of another metal ion. We employed a different approach of a direct solvothermal synthetic approach based on our hypothesis that first-row divalent transition metal ions (except Zn2+) could occupy only an octahedral position. By this method, we could successfully introduce Co2+ and Ni2+ ions precisely at the octahedral Zn2+ ion site of the [Zn4(μ3-OH)2]6+ oxo-cluster (b) to synthesize the present composites, PESD-2&3⊃Guest PCPs.

elements.content: PESD-2&3⊃Guest, [Zn2M2(μ3-OH)2(BTMB)2(DMF)3(MeOH)]·(DMF)2(H2O)2(MeOH) (M = Co and Ni), compounds were synthesized by mixing Zn­(NO3)2·4H2O/M­(NO3)2·6H2O (M = Co and Ni) metal salts and H3BTMB ligands, in a mixed solvent of dimethylformamide (DMF)/MeOH/H2O (2:1:1) at 100 °C (a). By utilizing X-ray florescence (XRF) analysis and changing the salt ratio of Zn­(NO3)2·4H2O and M­(NO3)2·6H2O (M = Co and Ni) in the starting reaction mixture, the desired ratio of Zn to Co or Ni (≈1:1) was achieved in the final product (see and for details).
elements.clean_text: PESD-2&3⊃Guest, [Zn2M2(μ3-OH)2(BTMB)2(DMF)3(MeOH)]⋅(DMF)2(H2O)2(MeOH) (M = Co and Ni), compounds were synthesized by mixing Zn(NO3)2⋅4H2O/M(NO3)2⋅6H2O (M = Co and Ni) metal salts and H3BTMB ligands, in a mixed solvent of dimethylformamide (DMF)/MeOH/H2O (2:1:1) at 100 °C (a). By utilizing X-ray florescence (XRF) analysis and changing the salt ratio of Zn(NO3)2⋅4H2O and M(NO3)2⋅6H2O (M = Co and Ni) in the starting reaction mixture, the desired ratio of Zn to Co or Ni (~1:1) was achieved in the final product (see  and  for details).

elements.content: The PESD-2&3⊃Guest were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis and found to be isostructural with PESD-1⊃Guest (, , ). The μ3-bridged hydroxyl proton was refined by single-crystal XRD analysis and confirmed by FTIR spectroscopic studies, which showed a characteristic peak at around 3615 cm–1, as shown in . For example, the single-crystal structure of PESD-2⊃Guest is shown in . They have a two-dimensional (2D) structure with an (8,6) net topology and form 1D channels along the b-axis similar to PESD-1⊃Guest. Each of the individual layers comprised rhombus-shaped [Zn2M2(μ3-OH)2]6+ (M = Co and Ni) tetranuclear clusters that were mutually connected via the BTMB3– ligands to form an (8,6) net. As shown in b, the [Zn2M 2 (μ3-OH)2]6+ cluster contains two octahedral M2+ ions (M = Co and Ni), two tetrahedral Zn2+ ions, and two μ3-hydroxyl moieties (OH–) that are present within the three-atom mean planes formed by the metal centers. The octahedral M2+ (M = Co and Ni) ions are coordinated to an oxygen atom of the three different carboxylate groups, two OH– fragments and a solvent molecule, whereas the tetrahedral Zn2+ ions are coordinated to oxygen atoms of three different carboxylate moieties along with only one of the OH– group. Even though the [Zn2M2(μ3-OH)2(BTMB)2 ] (M = Co and Ni) layers were comparatively dense, the voids formed between any two adjacent layers are large enough to accommodate all kinds of guest species.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystal Structures

The PESD-2&3⊃Guest were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis and found to be isostructural with PESD-1⊃Guest (, , ). The μ3-bridged hydroxyl proton was refined by single-crystal XRD analysis and confirmed by FTIR spectroscopic studies, which showed a characteristic peak at around 3615 cm-1, as shown in . For example, the single-crystal structure of PESD-2⊃Guest is shown in . They have a two-dimensional (2D) structure with an (8,6) net topology and form 1D channels along the b-axis similar to PESD-1⊃Guest. Each of the individual layers comprised rhombus-shaped [Zn2M2(μ3-OH)2]6+ (M = Co and Ni) tetranuclear clusters that were mutually connected via the BTMB3- ligands to form an (8,6) net. As shown in b, the [Zn2M 2 (μ3-OH)2]6+ cluster contains two octahedral M2+ ions (M = Co and Ni), two tetrahedral Zn2+ ions, and two μ3-hydroxyl moieties (OH-) that are present within the three-atom mean planes formed by the metal centers. The octahedral M2+ (M = Co and Ni) ions are coordinated to an oxygen atom of the three different carboxylate groups, two OH- fragments and a solvent molecule, whereas the tetrahedral Zn2+ ions are coordinated to oxygen atoms of three different carboxylate moieties along with only one of the OH- group. Even though the [Zn2M2(μ3-OH)2(BTMB)2 ] (M = Co and Ni) layers were comparatively dense, the voids formed between any two adjacent layers are large enough to accommodate all kinds of guest species.

elements.content: Energy-dispersive X-ray scanning electron microscope (EDX-SEM) analysis on single crystals in degassed phases PESD-2 and PESD-3 () indicated that the ratios of Zn and Co or Ni are almost equal, which agree with those obtained by XRF analysis. Moreover, EDX-SEM analysis also confirmed that Zn and Co (or Ni) X-ray maps are distributed uniformly throughout each single crystal, and hence the Zn and Co (or Ni) metal ions are present in the same PCP particles, but not the physical mixture of those PCPs formed with Zn and Co (or Ni) individually, which agrees with single-crystal XRD analysis. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns () of PESD-2&3⊃Guest are similar to that of PESD-1⊃Guest, indicating that they are isostructural. Moreover, these PXRD patterns of the as-synthesized phase are in reasonable agreement with their simulated patterns, indicating that the samples produced by all the different synthetic methods were pure homogeneous in nature (). Upon degassing of PESD-2&3⊃Guest at 250 °C, their PXRD patterns indicated that they are crystalline in the degassed phases and similar to those of degassed PESD-1 (). As a result, we could conclude that these three PCPs were isostructural frameworks not only in the as-synthesized phase but also in degassed phase. However, their crystallinity was slightly decreased, but the major peaks reasonably matched the simulated peaks based on the degassed crystal structure model of PESD-1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was measured for PESD-2&3⊃Guest under flowing N2 with a flow rate of 10 °C/min (). Coordination-free solvent molecules were removed below 135 °C for the two compounds, whereas the coordinated DMF solvent molecules were removed between 135 and 250 °C depending on the nature of the metal ions coordinated by DMF in the PCPs, to form degas phases similar to PESD-1. The essential point in these three, PESD-1–3, PCP analogues exhibits dissimilarities in the releasing temperature of their coordinated solvents, indicating the interactions between the OMSs and coordinated guest molecules were conspicuously different. The observed weight loss was around 29% for all the phases, which is in good agreement with the expected value of 30%. The onset of decomposition is around 400 °C for all the PCPs. Their thermal stability depends on the metal present in the oxo-cluster, [Zn2M2((μ3-OH)2]6+, and PESD-2 is the most stable compared with the other two analogues. Overall, the present PCPs possess better thermal stability compared with the M4O cluster contained in MOFs (∼350 °C).
elements.clean_text:

Moreover, EDX-SEM analysis also confirmed that Zn and Co (or Ni) X-ray maps are distributed uniformly throughout each single crystal, and hence the Zn and Co (or Ni) metal ions are present in the same PCP particles, but not the physical mixture of those PCPs formed with Zn and Co (or Ni) individually, which agrees with single-crystal XRD analysis. Moreover, these PXRD patterns of the as-synthesized phase are in reasonable agreement with their simulated patterns, indicating that the samples produced by all the different synthetic methods were pure homogeneous in nature (). Upon degassing of PESD-2&3⊃Guest at 250 °C, their PXRD patterns indicated that they are crystalline in the degassed phases and similar to those of degassed PESD-1 (). As a result, we could conclude that these three PCPs were isostructural frameworks not only in the as-synthesized phase but also in degassed phase. elements.content: The porosity of the series PESD-1, -2, and -3 was ascertained from a type-I isotherm using CO2 adsorption isotherms at 195 K (). They did not adsorb N2 at 77 K, probably owing to a microporous blocking effect at such a very low temperature. The BET surface areas were 295, 317, and 272 m2 g–1, and the Langmuir surface areas were 570, 662, and 560 m2 g–1 based on CO2 adsorption isotherms respectively for PESD-1, -2, and -3. The isosteric heats of H2 adsorptions were −7.15, −8.13, and −8.05 kJ mol–1 respectively for PESD-1, -2, and -3 calculated based on the viral equation with the data obtained at 77 and 87 K (inset in ). As predicted, composite PESD-2&3 PCPs exhibit a better surface area and heats of adsorption compared to the PESD-1 (Zn) analogue. Among them, PESD-2 (Co analogue) displays the highest surface area and heat of adsorption. Moreover, isosteric heats of H2 adsorption values are also high compared to many MOFs (for MOFs, usually in the range from −4 to −7 kJ mol–1), which could be due to OMSs present in PESD PCPs. The mechanism of OMSs and gas adsorption phenomenon in these bimetallic analogues could be explained as follows. The OMSs to the guest interaction basically depend on the electronegativity of the metals or metal ions including the number of OMSs present per metal ion. In our present study, all three compounds PESD-1–3 (Zn–Zn, Zn–Co, and Zn-Ni) contain a similar metal cluster of [Zn4O]6+ (PESD-1) and the composite cluster [Zn2M2O]6+ (M = Co or Ni) (PESD-2 and -3) in the degassed state. Moreover, all three compounds are isostructural, and the number of OMSs expected would be the same. The main difference is at the metal cluster core part, where octahedral coordinated Zn metal was replaced with Co (or Ni) respectively for PESD-2 and -3 (Zn–Co and Zn–Ni) analogues (). As observed in TGA, the coordinated DMF solvent molecules leave at ∼173, ∼189, and ∼231 °C respectively for Zn, Co, and Ni (PESD-1, -2, and -3) analogues. This is in good agreement with their respective electronegativity values of 1.65, 1.88, and 1.91 respectively for Zn, Co, and Ni metals. Moreover, the isosteric heats of H2 adsorptions values also reasonably agree with the TGA data and electronegativity values. However, in the case of the Ni (PESD-3) analogue, the isosteric heats of H2 adsorptions and also adsorption of other gases are slightly lower than those of the Co (PESD-2) analogue, due to low crystallinity observed for the degassed state ().
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption Study

The porosity of the series PESD-1, -2, and -3 was ascertained from a type-I isotherm using CO2 adsorption isotherms at 195 K (). They did not adsorb N2 at 77 K, probably owing to a microporous blocking effect at such a very low temperature. The BET surface areas were 295, 317, and 272 m2 g-1, and the Langmuir surface areas were 570, 662, and 560 m2 g-1 based on CO2 adsorption isotherms respectively for PESD-1, -2, and -3. The isosteric heats of H2 adsorptions were -7.15, -8.13, and -8.05 kJ mol-1 respectively for PESD-1, -2, and -3 calculated based on the viral equation with the data obtained at 77 and 87 K (inset in ). As predicted, composite PESD-2&3 PCPs exhibit a better surface area and heats of adsorption compared to the PESD-1 (Zn) analogue. Among them, PESD-2 (Co analogue) displays the highest surface area and heat of adsorption. Moreover, isosteric heats of H2 adsorption values are also high compared to many MOFs (for MOFs, usually in the range from -4 to -7 kJ mol-1), which could be due to OMSs present in PESD PCPs. The mechanism of OMSs and gas adsorption phenomenon in these bimetallic analogues could be explained as follows. The OMSs to the guest interaction basically depend on the electronegativity of the metals or metal ions including the number of OMSs present per metal ion. In our present study, all three compounds PESD-1-3 (Zn-Zn, Zn-Co, and Zn-Ni) contain a similar metal cluster of [Zn4O]6+ (PESD-1) and the composite cluster [Zn2M2O]6+ (M = Co or Ni) (PESD-2 and -3) in the degassed state. Moreover, all three compounds are isostructural, and the number of OMSs expected would be the same. The main difference is at the metal cluster core part, where octahedral coordinated Zn metal was replaced with Co (or Ni) respectively for PESD-2 and -3 (Zn-Co and Zn-Ni) analogues (). As observed in TGA, the coordinated DMF solvent molecules leave at ~173, ~189, and ~231 °C respectively for Zn, Co, and Ni (PESD-1, -2, and -3) analogues. This is in good agreement with their respective electronegativity values of 1.65, 1.88, and 1.91 respectively for Zn, Co, and Ni metals. Moreover, the isosteric heats of H2 adsorptions values also reasonably agree with the TGA data and electronegativity values. However, in the case of the Ni (PESD-3) analogue, the isosteric heats of H2 adsorptions and also adsorption of other gases are slightly lower than those of the Co (PESD-2) analogue, due to low crystallinity observed for the degassed state ().

elements.content: Contact angle measurements were performed on powdered samples of the three isostructural analogues PESD- 1, -2, and -3, to estimate their superhydrophobic behavior. The measurements carried out at various possible high temperatures on as-synthesized and as well as degassed samples separately. The contact angles measured on as-synthesized powder samples at room temperature (RT, ∼30 °C) of PESD- 1, -2 and -3 respectively were 155.5°, 159.3°, and 160.8° (, , ). Similarly, the contact angles measured at RT on degassed samples were 158.4°, 157.6°, and 158.8° respectively for PESD- 1, -2, and -3 (). Moreover, the roll-off angles were observed to be less than 10° for all three analogues, indicative of a superhydrophobic surface (Lotus behavior or self-cleaning). It is noteworthy that the MOFs/PCPs family of archetypal framework [Zn4O­(L) n ] formed a similar chemical formula of H3BTB ligands with a coordinating (RCOO – ) moiety at the para-position and others are hygroscopic in nature. However, similar contact angle measurements on the powdered samples of pure H3BTMB ligand alone did not have any contact angle, indicating that the ligand alone in uncoordinated state is hydrophilic in nature.
elements.clean_text:
Superhydrophobicity and Temperature-Dependent Stability Study

Contact angle measurements were performed on powdered samples of the three isostructural analogues PESD- 1, -2, and -3, to estimate their superhydrophobic behavior. The measurements carried out at various possible high temperatures on as-synthesized and as well as degassed samples separately. The contact angles measured on as-synthesized powder samples at room temperature (RT, ~30 °C) of PESD- 1, -2 and -3 respectively were 155.5°, 159.3°, and 160.8° (, , ). Similarly, the contact angles measured at RT on degassed samples were 158.4°, 157.6°, and 158.8° respectively for PESD- 1, -2, and -3 (). Moreover, the roll-off angles were observed to be less than 10° for all three analogues, indicative of a superhydrophobic surface (Lotus behavior or self-cleaning). It is noteworthy that the MOFs/PCPs family of archetypal framework [Zn4O(L) n ] formed a similar chemical formula of H3BTB ligands with a coordinating (RCOO - ) moiety at the para-position and others are hygroscopic in nature. However, similar contact angle measurements on the powdered samples of pure H3BTMB ligand alone did not have any contact angle, indicating that the ligand alone in uncoordinated state is hydrophilic in nature.

elements.content: The study on the superhydrophobic effect on the particle size and their hierarchical roughness revealed that the contact angles decreased with increasing particle size from a powder to pellet form ( and ), similar to our previous study (Cassie–Baxter model of superhydrophobicity). Moreover, we also carried out contact angle measurements on the powder samples of PESD- 1, -2 and -3 at different temperatures starting from RT to 90 °C, at 10 °C temperature intervals for each measurement ( and ). As shown in for the PESD-3 compound, all the powder samples showed high contact angles even at a high temperature for longer time periods. This is evidence that the present composite PCPs displaying a stable hydrophobic nature survive even at high temperature. However, as expected the contact angles were slightly decreased at high temperature. It could be due to water vapor starting to condense near its boiling point by reducing the roughness of the surface, similar to a lotus leaf. Indeed, at high temperature, most of the superhydrophobic PCPs including the lotus leaf could not preserve their hydrophobic surface. From the above observations, we conclude that this unique superhydrophobic behavior might be due to these PCPs (PESD-1, -2, and -3) having a strong affinity toward the air (or gas molecules) between the layers due to strong OMSs. The gaseous molecules (or air) repel liquid water without penetrating into the layers (Cassie–Baxter model of superhydrophobicity). In fact, even as-synthesized single crystal state, PESD-1, -2 and -3, PCPs lose some of the uncoordinated solvent molecules immediately in the open atmosphere, being replaced with atmosphere gaseous molecules (or air). Due to the above unique behavior, the current PCPs, PESD-1, -2, and -3, are superhydrophobic in all the synthesized states (powder and single crystals) and the degassed state, including at high temperatures (RT to 90 °C).

elements.content: We also examined the sorption ability of the two isostructural PESD-2 and -3 analogues, by taking them as a model study for three different six-membered-ring organic solvents with similar molecular size, but different polarity, such as aromatic and aliphatic solvents. The adsorption profiles of PESD-2 and -3 measured at 298 K on degassed samples using three different solvents (benzene, toluene, and cyclohexane) are displayed in (a) and (b). Surprisingly, the adsorption isotherms for aromatic solvents (benzene and toluene) displayed a gate-opening profile and enter the solvent molecules via the pores, whereas the aliphatic solvent molecules (cyclohexane) displayed gate-closing behavior and could not enter into the pores. This could be due to aliphatic organic solvents being excluded from the pores by corrugated and terminated aromatic hydrocarbon moieties toward the solvent interactive surface. These results clearly indicated that PESD-2 & 3 exhibits size, shape and surface interactions toward guest molecules. Moreover, these experiments clearly demonstrated that PESD-2 and -3 can accommodate a variety of aromatic solvents. Among PESD-1, -2 and -3 analogues, PESD-2 (Co) composite PCP shows the highest adsorption capacity of benzene and toluene solvent; this agrees with their surface area and heats of adsorption values of these analogues.
elements.clean_text:
Aromatic Solvent Selectivity and Oil Spill Cleanup Study

We also examined the sorption ability of the two isostructural PESD-2 and -3 analogues, by taking them as a model study for three different six-membered-ring organic solvents with similar molecular size, but different polarity, such as aromatic and aliphatic solvents. The adsorption profiles of PESD-2 and -3 measured at 298 K on degassed samples using three different solvents (benzene, toluene, and cyclohexane) are displayed in (a) and (b). Surprisingly, the adsorption isotherms for aromatic solvents (benzene and toluene) displayed a gate-opening profile and enter the solvent molecules via the pores, whereas the aliphatic solvent molecules (cyclohexane) displayed gate-closing behavior and could not enter into the pores. This could be due to aliphatic organic solvents being excluded from the pores by corrugated and terminated aromatic hydrocarbon moieties toward the solvent interactive surface. These results clearly indicated that PESD-2 & 3 exhibits size, shape and surface interactions toward guest molecules. Moreover, these experiments clearly demonstrated that PESD-2 and -3 can accommodate a variety of aromatic solvents. Among PESD-1, -2 and -3 analogues, PESD-2 (Co) composite PCP shows the highest adsorption capacity of benzene and toluene solvent; this agrees with their surface area and heats of adsorption values of these analogues.

elements.content: For real-time applications of the present composite superhydrophobic PCPs, we also carried out an oil spill cleanup study for PESD-2 and -3. In fact, the powder samples showing superhydrophobicity with contact angles of >150° (155.5°, 159.3°, and 160.8° respectively for PESD- 1, -2, and -3) were converted into pellets (hydrophobic surfaces observed in the pellet-disk form) of PESD-2 and -3 for the oil cleanup study. Pellets of PESD-2 and -3 were placed within a mixture consisting of an organic solvent/oil and water. Outstandingly, the pellets floated on the water surface and adsorbed organic solvents/oils selectively from the water (; see movie files 1–3, in the ). More precisely and quantitatively, 150 and 135 mg of PESD-2 and -3 pellet discs with surface areas of ∼1.7 5 and ∼1.5 cm2 could uptake ∼350 and ∼385 wt % of olive oil, respectively. Moreover, these samples could be reused for several cycles without losing its crystallinity and superhydrophobicity. These results evidenced that PESD-2 and -3 utilized the pores depending on the solvent and conditions used, along with the regular capillary action utilized by nonporous materials. Hence, the amount of absorbed solvent could be several times larger than the conventional nonporous superhydrophobic solids, which just utilize the capillary action in the organic solvents/oil spill cleanup process.

elements.content: In conclusion, we described a new de nova synthetic method for the synthesis of superhydrophobic composite PCPs with interesting stable bimetallic oxo-clusters. For this purpose, we utilized coordination priorities of first-row transition elements and achieved [Zn2M2O]6+ (M = Co or Ni) clusters, in which substitution of Co2+ or Ni2+ at an octahedral-coordinated Zn2+ position occurs. As designed, these new composite PCPs showing noticeably different coordination affinities with solvent molecules in raw phases converted to OMSs in their degassed phases. Furthermore, these interesting composite PCPs exhibit incredible superhydrophobic properties with contact angles of >150° even at high temperature, compared to conventional superhydrophobic materials. Fascinatingly, these new PCPs display selective adsorption toward aromatic solvents such as benzene and toluene over aliphatic solvents such as cyclohexane. Among PESD-1, -2, and -3 analogues, the PESD-2 (Co) composite PCP shows the highest surface area, isosteric heats of adsorptions, solvent adsorption capacity, etc. They also exhibit oil spill cleanup ability from the water surface in the powder form as well as pellet form. This study certainly provides a roadmap for engineering new composite porous materials for better water and thermal stability with the possibility of containing more OMSs for applications in catalysis and separation technology. In our next study, we report exciting results about water-stable green heterogeneous catalytic properties of these fascinating composite superhydrophobic PCPs.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we described a new de nova synthetic method for the synthesis of superhydrophobic composite PCPs with interesting stable bimetallic oxo-clusters. For this purpose, we utilized coordination priorities of first-row transition elements and achieved [Zn2M2O]6+ (M = Co or Ni) clusters, in which substitution of Co2+ or Ni2+ at an octahedral-coordinated Zn2+ position occurs. As designed, these new composite PCPs showing noticeably different coordination affinities with solvent molecules in raw phases converted to OMSs in their degassed phases. Furthermore, these interesting composite PCPs exhibit incredible superhydrophobic properties with contact angles of >150° even at high temperature, compared to conventional superhydrophobic materials. Fascinatingly, these new PCPs display selective adsorption toward aromatic solvents such as benzene and toluene over aliphatic solvents such as cyclohexane. Among PESD-1, -2, and -3 analogues, the PESD-2 (Co) composite PCP shows the highest surface area, isosteric heats of adsorptions, solvent adsorption capacity, etc. They also exhibit oil spill cleanup ability from the water surface in the powder form as well as pellet form. This study certainly provides a roadmap for engineering new composite porous materials for better water and thermal stability with the possibility of containing more OMSs for applications in catalysis and separation technology. In our next study, we report exciting results about water-stable green heterogeneous catalytic properties of these fascinating composite superhydrophobic PCPs.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

Zn(NO3)2⋅4H2O and methanol (MeOH) were purchased from Merck, and Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O, Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O, and N,N-dimethylformamide were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, USA, and used as received without further purification.

elements.content: In a 2 mL glass vial containing 1 mL of mixed solvent of DMF/MeOH/H2O (2:1:1), a solid mixture of ligand H3BTMB (11 mg, 0.025 mmol), Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (10.9 mg, 0.038 mmol), and Zn­(NO3)2·4H2O (6.54 mg, 0.025 mmol) was dissolved. To this reaction mixture was added 20 μL of deprotonating reagent of NaOH (0.01 M). After adding NaOH, the reaction mixture converted to a violet color precipitate with an initial pH of ∼6.0. The entire reaction mixture was heated in a temperature-controllable oven from RT (∼30 °C) to 100 °C, over a period of 4 h. Later, the reaction mixture was heated at a constant temperature of 100 °C for a period of 48 h. Finally, the reaction mixture was cooled from 100 °C to RT (∼30 °C) over a period of 6 h. The product contains homogeneous violet-colored flake-type crystals, which were isolated by washing with MeOH and air-dried. Yield: 17.5 mg, 86% observed based on 1 mol of H3BTMB. Elemental microanalysis for PESD-2⊃Guest, [Zn2Co2(μ3-OH)2(BTMB)2­(DMF)3(MeOH)]·(DMF)2(H2O)2­(MeOH)C71H79N5O23Zn2Co2, calculated (%): C, 52.67; H, 4.92; N, 4.33. Found (%): C, 52.23; H, 5.15; N, 4.10. Syntheses of large-scale products of both PESD-2⊃Guest and PESD-3⊃Guest were achieved by similar solvothermal condition methods using Teflon-lined autoclave (see for more details).

General Characterization Techniques

TGA was carried out using a Hitachi STA 7200 under a N2 flow with a 10 K min–1 ramp rate. The PXRD patterns were recorded using a Rigaku RINT powder X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements were performed at 223 K with a Rigaku AFC10 diffractometer with a Rigaku Saturn Kappa CCD system equipped with a MicroMax-007 HF/Vari-Max rotating-anode X-ray generator with confocal monochromatic Mo Kα radiation. Gas adsorption isotherms were carried out using a Belsorp Mini volumetric adsorption instrument, Bel Japan Inc, Japan. X-ray florescence analysis was carried out by using a Rigaku EDXL-300, Japan. FTIR spectra were recorded at 298 K using a Cary 639 FTIR with a Diamond ATR, Agilent Technologies, USA. SEM/EDX analysis was carried out using a JEOL JED-2300.
elements.clean_text:
Large-Scale Syntheses of PESD-2⊃Guest and PESD-3⊃Guest

Syntheses of large-scale products of both PESD-2⊃Guest and PESD-3⊃Guest were achieved by similar solvothermal condition methods using Teflon-lined autoclave (see  for more details).

General Characterization Techniques

TGA was carried out using a Hitachi STA 7200 under a N2 flow with a 10 K min-1 ramp rate. The PXRD patterns were recorded using a Rigaku RINT powder X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements were performed at 223 K with a Rigaku AFC10 diffractometer with a Rigaku Saturn Kappa CCD system equipped with a MicroMax-007 HF/Vari-Max rotating-anode X-ray generator with confocal monochromatic Mo Kα radiation. Gas adsorption isotherms were carried out using a Belsorp Mini volumetric adsorption instrument, Bel Japan Inc, Japan. X-ray florescence analysis was carried out by using a Rigaku EDXL-300, Japan. FTIR spectra were recorded at 298 K using a Cary 639 FTIR with a Diamond ATR, Agilent Technologies, USA. SEM/EDX analysis was carried out using a JEOL JED-2300.

elements.content: Contact angles were measured on powder samples using a Holmarc contact angle meter with a rotatable substrate holder, temperature controller, and automated water dispenser unit, model no. HO-IAD-CAM-01B, Holmarc Opto-Mechtronics LTD, India. To perform contact angle measurements, the powder samples of ∼30 mg of PESD-1, -2, and -3 were deposited on an aluminum substrate bed. Using a glass slide the powder samples were pressed to make a flat surface. A 20 μL water droplet was released slowly on the flat surface of the powder samples using an automated 100 μL water dispenser unit. Later, the droplet image was captured using a high-performance charge-coupled device (CCD) sensor. B-Spline drop snake analysis was used to perform analysis of the contact angles of all the powder samples. Similarly, temperature-dependent contact angles were also measured at room temperature (∼30 °C) to 90 °C in 10 °C step intervals. To achieve these high temperatures, the substrate bed was heated with the help of temperature controller equipment. At high temperature, the contact angles were measured relatively quickly (∼3 min) after dropping the water droplet due to the water evaporation problem.
elements.clean_text:
Contact Angle Measurements

Contact angles were measured on powder samples using a Holmarc contact angle meter with a rotatable substrate holder, temperature controller, and automated water dispenser unit, model no. HO-IAD-CAM-01B, Holmarc Opto-Mechtronics LTD, India. To perform contact angle measurements, the powder samples of ~30 mg of PESD-1, -2, and -3 were deposited on an aluminum substrate bed. Using a glass slide the powder samples were pressed to make a flat surface. A 20 μL water droplet was released slowly on the flat surface of the powder samples using an automated 100 μL water dispenser unit. Later, the droplet image was captured using a high-performance charge-coupled device (CCD) sensor. B-Spline drop snake analysis was used to perform analysis of the contact angles of all the powder samples. Similarly, temperature-dependent contact angles were also measured at room temperature (~30 °C) to 90 °C in 10 °C step intervals. To achieve these high temperatures, the substrate bed was heated with the help of temperature controller equipment. At high temperature, the contact angles were measured relatively quickly (~3 min) after dropping the water droplet due to the water evaporation problem.

elements.content: Experiments for removing organic solvents and oil spills from the water surface were carried out by converting powder samples of PESD-2 and -3 into pellet discs (∼2.2 cm2 area) by applying 4–6 MPa of pressure. The organic solvents such as toluene, hexane, benzene, and olive oil labeled with Oil Blue 35 (to distinguish colorless oils from colorless water) were dropped in water in a Petri dish. Pellet discs of PESD-2 and -3 were dropped in the middle of the organic solvent or oil drop on the water surface. After the pellet discs adsorbed the organic solvent or oil drop, the adsorbed samples were removed from the water surface and the same samples were used for quantitative analysis and other characterizations.
elements.clean_text:
Oil Spill Cleanup Study

Experiments for removing organic solvents and oil spills from the water surface were carried out by converting powder samples of PESD-2 and -3 into pellet discs (~2.2 cm2 area) by applying 4-6 MPa of pressure. The organic solvents such as toluene, hexane, benzene, and olive oil labeled with Oil Blue 35 (to distinguish colorless oils from colorless water) were dropped in water in a Petri dish. Pellet discs of PESD-2 and -3 were dropped in the middle of the organic solvent or oil drop on the water surface. After the pellet discs adsorbed the organic solvent or oil drop, the adsorbed samples were removed from the water surface and the same samples were used for quantitative analysis and other characterizations.

cln_elements.content: In a 2 mL glass vial containing 1 mL of mixed solvent of DMF/MeOH/H2O (2:1:1), a solid mixture of ligand H3BTMB (11 mg, 0.025 mmol), Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (10.9 mg, 0.038 mmol), and Zn­(NO3)2·4H2O (6.54 mg, 0.025 mmol) was dissolved. To this reaction mixture was added 20 μL of deprotonating reagent of NaOH (0.01 M). After adding NaOH, the reaction mixture converted to a violet color precipitate with an initial pH of ∼6.0. The entire reaction mixture was heated in a temperature-controllable oven from RT (∼30 °C) to 100 °C, over a period of 4 h. Later, the reaction mixture was heated at a constant temperature of 100 °C for a period of 48 h. Finally, the reaction mixture was cooled from 100 °C to RT (∼30 °C) over a period of 6 h. The product contains homogeneous violet-colored flake-type crystals, which were isolated by washing with MeOH and air-dried. Yield: 17.5 mg, 86% observed based on 1 mol of H3BTMB. Elemental microanalysis for PESD-2⊃Guest, [Zn2Co2(μ3-OH)2(BTMB)2­(DMF)3(MeOH)]·(DMF)2(H2O)2­(MeOH)C71H79N5O23Zn2Co2, calculated (%): C, 52.67; H, 4.92; N, 4.33. Found (%): C, 52.23; H, 5.15; N, 4.10. FT-IR (4000–525 cm–1): 3616 (s, w), 3381 (br, w), 3061 (s, w), 2931 (s, w), 1649­(vs), 1609 (vs), 1588 (s), 1568 (vs), 1495 (w), 1441 (m), 1413 (m), 1373 (vs), 1263 (m), 1247 (m), 1157 (w), 1105 (m), 1077 (m), 1055 (w), 1028 (m), 876 (m), 802 (s), 761 (vs), 715 (m), 693 (s), 686 (s), 680 (vs), 653 (m).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis and Characterization of PESD-2⊃Guest

In a 2 mL glass vial containing 1 mL of mixed solvent of DMF/MeOH/H2O (2:1:1), a solid mixture of ligand H3BTMB (11 mg, 0.025 mmol), Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (10.9 mg, 0.038 mmol), and Zn(NO3)2⋅4H2O (6.54 mg, 0.025 mmol) was dissolved. To this reaction mixture was added 20 μL of deprotonating reagent of NaOH (0.01 M). After adding NaOH, the reaction mixture converted to a violet color precipitate with an initial pH of ~6.0. The entire reaction mixture was heated in a temperature-controllable oven from RT (~30 °C) to 100 °C, over a period of 4 h. Later, the reaction mixture was heated at a constant temperature of 100 °C for a period of 48 h. Finally, the reaction mixture was cooled from 100 °C to RT (~30 °C) over a period of 6 h. The product contains homogeneous violet-colored flake-type crystals, which were isolated by washing with MeOH and air-dried. Yield: 17.5 mg, 86% observed based on 1 mol of H3BTMB. Elemental microanalysis for PESD-2⊃Guest, [Zn2Co2(μ3-OH)2(BTMB)2(DMF)3(MeOH)]⋅(DMF)2(H2O)2(MeOH)C71H79N5O23Zn2Co2, calculated (%): C, 52.67; H, 4.92; N, 4.33. Found (%): C, 52.23; H, 5.15; N, 4.10. FT-IR (4000-525 cm-1): 3616 (s, w), 3381 (br, w), 3061 (s, w), 2931 (s, w), 1649(vs), 1609 (vs), 1588 (s), 1568 (vs), 1495 (w), 1441 (m), 1413 (m), 1373 (vs), 1263 (m), 1247 (m), 1157 (w), 1105 (m), 1077 (m), 1055 (w), 1028 (m), 876 (m), 802 (s), 761 (vs), 715 (m), 693 (s), 686 (s), 680 (vs), 653 (m).

cln_elements.content:
The porosity of the series PESD-1, -2, and -3 was ascertained from a type-I isotherm using CO2 adsorption isotherms at 195 K (). They did not adsorb N2 at 77 K, probably owing to a microporous blocking effect at such a very low temperature. The BET surface areas were 295, 317, and 272 m2 g–1, and the Langmuir surface areas were 570, 662, and 560 m2 g–1 based on CO2 adsorption isotherms respectively for PESD-1, -2, and -3. The isosteric heats of H2 adsorptions were −7.15, −8.13, and −8.05 kJ mol–1 respectively for PESD-1, -2, and -3 calculated based on the viral equation with the data obtained at 77 and 87 K (inset in ). As predicted, composite PESD-2&3 PCPs exhibit a better surface area and heats of adsorption compared to the PESD-1 (Zn) analogue. Among them, PESD-2 (Co analogue) displays the highest surface area and heat of adsorption. Moreover, isosteric heats of H2 adsorption values are also high compared to many MOFs (for MOFs, usually in the range from −4 to −7 kJ mol–1), which could be due to OMSs present in PESD PCPs. The mechanism of OMSs and gas adsorption phenomenon in these bimetallic analogues could be explained as follows. The OMSs to the guest interaction basically depend on the electronegativity of the metals or metal ions including the number of OMSs present per metal ion. In our present study, all three compounds PESD-1–3 (Zn–Zn, Zn–Co, and Zn-Ni) contain a similar metal cluster of [Zn4O]6+ (PESD-1) and the composite cluster [Zn2M2O]6+ (M = Co or Ni) (PESD-2 and -3) in the degassed state. Moreover, all three compounds are isostructural, and the number of OMSs expected would be the same. The main difference is at the metal cluster core part, where octahedral coordinated Zn metal was replaced with Co (or Ni) respectively for PESD-2 and -3 (Zn–Co and Zn–Ni) analogues (). As observed in TGA, the coordinated DMF solvent molecules leave at ∼173, ∼189, and ∼231 °C respectively for Zn, Co, and Ni (PESD-1, -2, and -3) analogues. This is in good agreement with their respective electronegativity values of 1.65, 1.88, and 1.91 respectively for Zn, Co, and Ni metals. Moreover, the isosteric heats of H2 adsorptions values also reasonably agree with the TGA data and electronegativity values. However, in the case of the Ni (PESD-3) analogue, the isosteric heats of H2 adsorptions and also adsorption of other gases are slightly lower than those of the Co (PESD-2) analogue, due to low crystallinity observed for the degassed state ().

Superhydrophobicity and Temperature-Dependent Stability Study

Contact angle measurements were performed on powdered samples of the three isostructural analogues PESD- 1, -2, and -3, to estimate their superhydrophobic behavior. The measurements carried out at various possible high temperatures on as-synthesized and as well as degassed samples separately. The contact angles measured on as-synthesized powder samples at room temperature (RT, ∼30 °C) of PESD- 1, -2 and -3 respectively were 155.5°, 159.3°, and 160.8° (, , ). Similarly, the contact angles measured at RT on degassed samples were 158.4°, 157.6°, and 158.8° respectively for PESD- 1, -2, and -3 (). Moreover, the roll-off angles were observed to be less than 10° for all three analogues, indicative of a superhydrophobic surface (Lotus behavior or self-cleaning). It is noteworthy that the MOFs/PCPs family of archetypal framework [Zn4O­(L) n ] formed a similar chemical formula of H3BTB ligands with a coordinating (RCOO – ) moiety at the para-position and others are hygroscopic in nature. However, similar contact angle measurements on the powdered samples of pure H3BTMB ligand alone did not have any contact angle, indicating that the ligand alone in uncoordinated state is hydrophilic in nature.

For real-time applications of the present composite superhydrophobic PCPs, we also carried out an oil spill cleanup study for PESD-2 and -3. In fact, the powder samples showing superhydrophobicity with contact angles of >150° (155.5°, 159.3°, and 160.8° respectively for PESD- 1, -2, and -3) were converted into pellets (hydrophobic surfaces observed in the pellet-disk form) of PESD-2 and -3 for the oil cleanup study. Pellets of PESD-2 and -3 were placed within a mixture consisting of an organic solvent/oil and water. Outstandingly, the pellets floated on the water surface and adsorbed organic solvents/oils selectively from the water (; see movie files 1–3, in the ). More precisely and quantitatively, 150 and 135 mg of PESD-2 and -3 pellet discs with surface areas of ∼1.7 5 and ∼1.5 cm2 could uptake ∼350 and ∼385 wt % of olive oil, respectively. Moreover, these samples could be reused for several cycles without losing its crystallinity and superhydrophobicity. These results evidenced that PESD-2 and -3 utilized the pores depending on the solvent and conditions used, along with the regular capillary action utilized by nonporous materials. Hence, the amount of absorbed solvent could be several times larger than the conventional nonporous superhydrophobic solids, which just utilize the capillary action in the organic solvents/oil spill cleanup process.

metadata.title:
Temperature-Stable
Compelled Composite Superhydrophobic
Porous Coordination Polymers Achieved via an Unattainable de Novo Synthetic Method
